case_title: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX, ASSAM vs KEDARMALL KESHARDEO
complaint_summary: Dispute regarding the validity and registration of a partnership deed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
investigation_summary: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred three questions of law concerning the interpretation of the partnership deed dated February 25, 1953, and the jurisdiction of the Commissioner under section 33-B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
judgment_summary: The court held that Smt. Tribeni Debi was a partner in a representative capacity and not in a dual capacity. The minor, Sri Gobindram Bajaj, was not made a full-fledged partner liable for losses. The partnership deed was valid, and the assessee-firm was entitled to registration under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Commissioner had jurisdiction under section 33-B of the repealed Act, as per section 297(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
Decision_or_verdict: Answered in the affirmative; the Tribunal's decisions were upheld.
legal_arguments: Section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
Section 33-B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
Section 4, 5, and 30 of the Indian Partnership Act
citations: Kalawati Devi Harlalka v. Commissioner of Income-tax ((1967) 66 ITR 680 (SC))
Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dwarkadas Khetan & Co. ((1961) 41 ITR 528)
N. T. Patel & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax ((1961) 42 ITR 224)
Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bagyalakshmi & Co. ((1965) 55 ITR 660 (SC))
Commissioner of Income-tax v. A. Abdul Rahim & Co. ((1965) 55 ITR 651 (SC))
Ram Laxman Sugar Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax ((1967) 66 ITR 613 (SC))
key_issues: Validity of partnership deed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
Jurisdiction of Commissioner under section 33-B post-repeal of the Act
Interpretation of partnership deed regarding minor's inclusion

key_findings.minor_status: A minor cannot be a full-fledged partner under section 30 of the Indian Partnership Act.
key_findings.registration_validity: The partnership deed was valid and genuine, and the firm was entitled to registration under section 26-A of the Income-tax Act.
key_findings.jurisdiction: The Commissioner retained jurisdiction under section 33-B of the repealed Income-tax Act, 1922, due to section 297(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

question_1.sub_question_a: Smt. Tribeni Debi was a partner in a representative capacity.
question_1.sub_question_b: The minor, Sri Gobindram Bajaj, was not made a full-fledged partner liable for losses.
question_1.sub_question_c: Smt. Tribeni Debi was not a partner in a dual capacity, and the deed of partnership was not invalid.
question_1.sub_question_d: Smt. Tribeni Debi and her minor son, Sri Gobindram Bajaj, had not been made partners jointly, and their individual shares were not required to be specified.

questions_of_law.question_2: The Tribunal was justified in law in holding that the assessee-firm constituted under the deed of partnership dated February 25, 1953, was entitled to registration and in setting aside the order of the Commissioner under section 33-B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
questions_of_law.question_3: The Commissioner of Income-Tax could invoke jurisdiction under section 33-B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, even after its repeal by section 297 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

legal_terms.Partnership: A relation between persons who agree to share profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all.
legal_terms.Registration: Legal recognition of a partnership deed under tax laws.

words_and_phrases.Representative Capacity: Acting on behalf of another individual or entity.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the interpretation of a partnership deed and its implications under tax law. The court upheld the Tribunal's decision, affirming the validity of the partnership deed and the jurisdiction of the Commissioner under section 33-B of the repealed Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
